--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "ma_lac84" <martilaszlo@...> wrote:
[snip]
> =
cycle is an infinite one. At a moment (let's say, after 2 or 3 time
> proce=
ssing of the instructions in the while cycle) the testing
> terminates, wit=
hout any exception rasing, or error message, the
> application simply stops=
. I suppose is something about timeout... 
(??)
> 

Right, you'll need to d=
o a little work to get JUnit to get any failed 
assertions back to JUnit.  =
Or use one of the test classes discussed 
in the links below.  By itself, J=
Unit doesn't have a timeout, for 
example, but check out Matt Albrecht's Gr=
oboUtils (see link below), 
that in fact is supported, so you aren't left h=
anging because of a 
runaway thread.  

This leads into another point: in a=
ddition to Simon's points, I'd 
also suggest that, in keeping with the phil=
osophy of JUnit, you try 
to make your test run quickly, perhaps by configu=
ring parameters, or 
sing mock objects, etc.

Matt Albrecht has written a g=
ood review of the issue, including 
source code, and includes a reference t=
o Andy Schneider's original 
JavaWorld article:
http://today.java.net/pub/a=
/today/2003/08/06/multithreadedTests.html

Other tips from this newsgroup:
=
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/message/17611
